question: Question_07_(c)
sols:
Using the Jacobian from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH215/December_2011/Question_7_(b)}{7
(b)} we find the linearization of the system in the critical points.

\textbf{Critical point $y_0 = (0,0)$}

\begin{align*}J(0,0) = \begin{pmatrix} 2 & 0\\ 0 & 1\end{pmatrix}.\end{align*}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  This matrix is diagonal and so the diagonal elements are the
  eigenvalues
\item
  This matrix is \emph{positive definite} since its two eigenvalues
  $1, 2$ are positive. All positive eigenvalues indicate that the
  critical point $(0,0)$ is an \textbf{unstable node}.
\item
  The eigenvector for the eigenvalue $1$ is
  $\begin{pmatrix} 0\\1\end{pmatrix}$.
\item
  The eigenvector for the eigenvalue $2$ is
  $\begin{pmatrix} 1\\0\end{pmatrix}$.
\item
  The linearized critical point in the phase space is on the following
  figure:
\end{itemize}

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Fig_215_2011_7c1.jpg}
\end{description}

\textbf{Critical point $y_0 = (2,0)$}

\begin{align*}J(2,0) =\begin{pmatrix} -2 & -2\\ 0 & -1\end{pmatrix}.\end{align*}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The eigenvalues are $-2, -1$, because a triangular matrix has its
  eigenvalues on the diagonal. The eigenvalues are both negative and
  hence, the matrix is \emph{negative definite} and this critical point
  is a \textbf{stable node}.
\item
  The eigenvector for the eigenvalue $-2$ is
  $\begin{pmatrix} 1\\0\end{pmatrix}$ because of the triangular shape of
  the matrix.
\item
  For the other eigenvector we need to work a little more and calculate
  the null space of $\displaystyle J(2,0) - (-1I)$:
\end{itemize}

$(J(2,0)+1I)(v_1,v_2)^T = \begin{pmatrix}-1 & -2\\0&0\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}v_1\\ v_2\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}-v_1 - 2v_2\\0\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}0\\0\end{pmatrix}$

Hence, $v_1 = -2v_2$

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  We find the the eigenvector for $-1$ is
  $\begin{pmatrix} -2\\1\end{pmatrix}$.
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The linearized critical point in the phase space is on the following
  figure:
\end{itemize}

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Fig_215_2011_7c2.jpg}
\caption{Phase space of critical point (2,0)}
\end{figure}

\textbf{Critical point $y_0 = (1,1)$}

\begin{align*}J(1,1) = \begin{pmatrix}-1 & -1\\ -1  & 0\end{pmatrix}.\end{align*}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  For the eigenvalues we calculate
\end{itemize}

$det\begin{pmatrix}-1-\lambda & -1\\ -1  & -\lambda\end{pmatrix} = \lambda^2 + \lambda - 1 = 0$

$\lambda = \frac{-1\pm\sqrt{5}}{2}$

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The eigenvalue for $\frac{-1-\sqrt5}{2}$ is the null space of
\end{itemize}

$\begin{pmatrix} -1+\frac{1+\sqrt5}{2} & -1\\ -1 & \frac{1+\sqrt5}{2}\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}v_1\\v_2\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}0\\0\end{pmatrix}$

$v_1 = \frac{1+\sqrt5}{2} v_2$

so that the eigenvector is $\begin{pmatrix}1+\sqrt5\\2\end{pmatrix}$.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The eigenvalue for $\frac{-1+\sqrt5}{2}$ is the null space of
\end{itemize}

$\begin{pmatrix} -1+\frac{1-\sqrt5}{2} & -1\\ -1 & \frac{1-\sqrt5}{2}\end{pmatrix}\begin{pmatrix}v_1\\v_2\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}0\\0\end{pmatrix}$

$v_1 = \frac{1-\sqrt5}{2} v_2$

and the eigenvector is $\begin{pmatrix}1-\sqrt5\\2\end{pmatrix}$.

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Because one eigenvalue is positive, the other negative, the critical
  point is not asymptotically stable. Along the eigenvector for
  $\frac{-1+\sqrt5}{2}$, the solution moves away from the critical
  point, along the eigenvector for $\frac{-1-\sqrt{5}}{2}$, the solution
  moves towards the critical point. Since the eigenvalues do not have
  the same sign, the matrix is \emph{indefinite} and the equilibrium is
  a \textbf{saddle point}.
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  See the following figure:
\end{itemize}

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Fig_215_2011_7c3.jpg}
\end{description}
hints:
For each of the three equilibrium points, calculate the eigenvalues of
the corresponding Jacobian matrix.

For your plots, find the eigenvectors corresponding to these
eigenvalues. Remember that solutions which start on an eigenvector, stay
on this eigenvector.
